item.title: About Me
item.description:
The Architect’s Manifesto

“We shape our tools, and thereafter our tools shape us.” — Marshall McLuhan

I am Virtual Sachin, a Technical Architect focused on building scalable, resilient, and human-centric software systems. My career is defined by a relentless pursuit of simplicity in complex environments. I don’t just write code; I design ecosystems where code can thrive.

My Philosophy

  1. Complexity is the Enemy: Any fool can write code that a computer can understand. Good programmers write code that humans can understand.
  2. Infrastructure as Art: I treat infrastructure with the same rigor as application code. Immutable, reproducible, and self-healing.
  3. Data Gravity: Architecture follows data. Understanding how information flows is key to designing the pipes that carry it.

Technical Radar

Core Competencies

  • Distributed Systems: Event-driven architectures, Microservices, CAP Theorem navigation.
  • Cloud Native: Kubernetes (EKS/AKS), Docker, Helm, Istio.
  • Infrastructure as Code: Terraform, Ansible, Pulumi.

Languages

  • Expert: Go (Golang), Python, TypeScript.
  • Proficient: Rust, Java, Bash.
  • Curious: Zig, Elixir.

Data & Storage

  • SQL: PostgreSQL, CockroachDB.
  • NoSQL: DynamoDB, Cassandra, Redis.
  • Streaming: Apache Kafka, NATS JetStream.

Experience Highlights

Principal Architect @ TechGiant Corp

Lead the migration of a monolithic e-commerce platform handling 50k RPS to a federated microservices architecture.

item.title: Project Nebula: Serverless Event Bus
item.description: A multi-region serverless event bus capable of handling 50M+ events per day with <200ms E2E latency.

item.title: Project Titan: Monolith to Microservices
item.description: Strangler Fig migration of a 10-year-old Java monolith to a federated Go microservices mesh.

item.title: BGP Attributes: Using Local Pref to Save Bandwidth Costs
item.description: I learned very quickly that BGP isn’t just a routing protocol. It is a financial instrument. Here is how we used Local Pref to slash bandwidth costs.

item.title: IPv4 Exhaustion is Real: My Strategy for IPv6 Dual Stacking
item.description: We ran out of allocatable IPv4 blocks. This wasn’t a theoretical exercise; it was an operational crisis. Here is the deep dive into how we architected the transition to IPv6.

item.title: P2V Nightmares: Migrating Physical Linux Boxes to VMware ESXi
item.description: The promise of P2V (Physical-to-Virtual) was seamless migration. But when I tried to virtualize our Billing Server, I ended up with a Kernel Panic and had to perform open-heart surgery on the OS.

item.title: Capacity Planning with Cacti: Predicting the Bandwidth Cliff
item.description: In the pre-cloud era, a 1 Gbps link was exactly 1 Gbps. If traffic hit 1.1 Gbps, the network broke. Here is how I used Cacti trend lines to predict a bandwidth cliff and prevent a catastrophic outage.

item.title: Observability on a Budget: RANCID + Observium
item.description: We built our own Network Operations Center (NOC) stack with RANCID and Observium. It wasn’t pretty, but it was bulletproof. Here is how we achieved total network observability for $0.

item.title: Firewall Hell: Managing Policies Across Cisco PIX, Juniper, and Fortinet
item.description: On paper, a multi-vendor security strategy sounds sophisticated. In the trenches, it is a nightmare. Managing one vendor is a job; managing three is a punishment.

item.title: Building a Data Center from Scratch: The Cabling Nightmare
item.description: For those of us who have built the infrastructure that the cloud sits on, we know the truth. The cloud has weight. It has heat. And it has miles of copper.

item.title: The Route Redistribution Loop that Took Down the Core
item.description: I effectively DDoS-ed our own control plane from the inside. Here is the story of how I melted a core router by forgetting one line of code.

item.title: Debugging the Air: Troubleshooting Packet Loss on WiMAX & RF Links
item.description: For thousands of customers, ‘The Cloud’ is a focused beam of radio waves. I learned that you can’t route-map your way around a building crane.

item.title: The Night the Fiber Cut: Lessons in WAN Redundancy
item.description: The primary fiber was dead. The backup links were stalling. I learned a lesson that no textbook could teach: Redundancy is only real if you test it.
